node.title: Itterative solver for a highly non-linear problem
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I am solving a problem which is highly non-linear, and iterative solvers failed due do the convergence. Now I am running my problem with a direct solver, but at a very high computational cost. Is there any suggestion for me to use iterative solver and still get convergence?
Thanks,
Ali

Hello
How many variables?
Can you describe the physics involved?
Also could please attach the convergence logs for an iterative and a direct solver?
If you could turn on the residual prints with
[Debug]
  show_var_residual_norms = true
[]

Also are the nonlinear iterations diverging? Or the linear iterations? Using a direct solver typically mostly influences the latter
Guillaume

I can do that for future simulations. In my simulation, phase field and navier stokes are fully coupled.
 Elems:                   
    Total:                 2250
    Local:                 24
    Min/Max/Avg:           23/24/23
  Num Subdomains:          1
  Num Partitions:          94
  Partitioner:             metis

Nonlinear System:
  Num DOFs:                11780
  Num Local DOFs:          205
  Variables:               { "vel_x" "vel_y" "p" "c" "w" } 
  Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE" 
  Approximation Orders:    "FIRST"

Can you drop pressure to zero-th order?
In incompressible flow it acts as a Lagrange multiplier and the numbers of degrees of freedom on this are best limited

I don't actually think that zeroth order pressure is stable. Trying it out on a test problem it yields a singular matrix. If you wanted to do constant monomial for pressure you'd likely need to add discontinuous galerkin face flux terms for the mass equation.
But for the variables used here, @alimostafavi24, you do have to make sure you're using pressure stabilization if you're going to do equal order discretization with velocity. I don't know if you're already doing that?
If you want something other than LU for Navier-Stokes, you're probably going to want to explore field split options. You can look at some discussion on #22405.

node.title: Aspect Ratio Postprocessing
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I am solving cahn-hilliard equation and I solved for the order parameter. I am not very familiar with post-processing in MOOSE. The initial condition is the elliptical domain and then the domain evolves and oscillated as it can seen in the attached image. What I need is to get the aspect ratio in each time step and plot it vs time. I would highly appreciate it if someone can tell me how I can get the aspect ratio and plot it vs time.

Thank you,
Ali
@dschwen do you have any suggestion for the kind of aspect ratio postprocessor this user is asking for? This kind of seems like it would be a nontrivial postprocessor to implement
We need some sort of "multi-quantity" postprocessor. Would have been a good base for the PressureDrop PP too

node.title: Why did the hypre parameters I modified fail to take effect？
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone! May I ask a question?
When I modify in moose
-pc_hypre_boomeramg_strong_threshold = 0.7
It outputs


But the residuals didn't change, did this step not work？
Lily

Can you try -pc_hypre_boomeramg_strong_threshold 0.7
it works fine for me

Thank you so much!
Lily

node.title: Solution Divergence
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I have a model which perfectly converge on my desktop computer with 8 CPUs. However, it diverges when I run on HPC with 8 CPUs either! What could be the reason for that? Could it be because of PETHC?
Thanks,
Ali

could be that your problem is poorly conditioned, so the perturbation of a slightly different architecture sends it on a path of non-convergence. Or it could be something else. In order to better determine what the problem might be, it would be helpful for you to share the nonlinear and linear iteration history of the failed solve including the non-convergence reason at the end of the nonlinear solve

node.title: Access to MARMOT
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Developer,
I would like to access MARMOT to study grain growth with Phase field and mechanical coupling model,and be instructed to contact the moose-users group. What should I do, thanks in advance!
Best,
Wei

Please go to (https://inl.gov/ncrc/) and see the "How NCRC Works" link on that page. Your institution must have a license agreement with INL in place, and all approved users must be evaluated on a case-by-case basis. On that page, there is also an email to submit a question to the NCRC for other questions you may have regarding access.
Thanks for your good instructions. I will fill in the application materials and look forward to using Marmot.

Dear cticenhour,
Thanks for your reply.I read the webpage carefully: INL Modeling and Simulation Software. I still have some doubts and hope to get your answers.@cticenhour
First, as a PhD student from a Chinese university instead of a native American university, can I get a license to use marmot?
Second, if I am eligible for a marmot license, what should I or my school pay?
Kind regards,
Wei Peng
East China University of Science and Technology
School of Mechanical and Power Engineering

As I am not a member of the access team for MARMOT or our other codes, I am not able to answer these questions. Please submit it to the form on the Access page I sent to you previously, or to the contacts on the "Access Instructions" page linked just above that form.

Most of the phase-field models including grain growth are already available in MOOSE. There are examples of phase-field and mechanics coupling in the 'combined' module. You can learn from these examples and build models around them. What do you need from MARMOT specifically?

My research direction is to study the grain growth and failure mechanism of ultra-fine or nanocrystalline under the interaction of mechanical field and temperature field. I read the article by L. Zhao.

On the plastic driving force of grain boundary migration: A fully coupled phase field and crystal plasticity model

His model is a coupled model of crystal plasticity and phase field, which is simulated by MARMOT. So, using MARMOT may be a good choice for me.
And in the combined example, only the linear elasticity is coupled into the phase field, there is no example of coupled crystal plasticity. I tried to couple j2 into the phase field last month, but failed. #16577

HI @cticenhour ,
The link you provided here for MARMOT (https://moose.inl.gov/marmot/SitePages/Access.aspx) no longer works.
Can you please provide an updated link?
Thank you very much

To ask for access to MARMOT you ll need to apply here
https://ncrcaims.inl.gov/Identity/Account/Login

Thanks @GiudGiud - I updated my post to reflect going to the NCRC home page https://inl.gov/ncrc.
@KamalnathOSU thanks to you for pointing out the broken link!

Thank you guys for your prompt response !
I want to simulate uniaxial compression of cylinder till plastic deformation (see the image below). Do you guys have any example in MOOSE that is similar to this ?

Hi Guys !
I got confused with the MARMOT(https://github.com/MAteRialMOdelingToolbox/Marmot) library  with the MARMOT application. The MARMOT which I need is actually open-source.

node.title: March 2023 Newsletter
node.bodyText:
The March 2023 MOOSE Newsletter has been released! A summary of the content is below:

MOOSE Improvements

Customized userobject / postprocessor execution order


libMesh-level Changes

2023.03.02 Update: Change Notes
2023.03.29 Update: Change Notes


Packaged VTK (moose-libmesh-vtk) updated to 9.2.6
Various bug fixes and enhancements

VectorPostprocessor parallel bug identified by ANL researchers was fixed through improved default synchronization.

node.title: How to use geometric multigrid preprocessing(mg)？
node.bodyText:
Hello, everyone! May I ask a question?
When I use mg, it seems that geometric information cannot be applied, only one layer can be applied. Could you please tell me whether multiple layers of mg can be used？
Thanks!
Lily

Hello
How are you using geometric multigrid from MOOSE?
Guillaume

I do this by using the option -pc_type mg.
Lily

We do not have handles for true geometric multigrid in MOOSE at this time, although I know it is on @roystgnr's wish-list. You can see some geometric multigrid at the libMesh level in libMesh/libmesh#2047

Thanks a lot!
Lily

node.title: Impose a dirichlet boundary condition on one component of a vertor variable and ignore the other components
node.bodyText:
hello，I want impose a dirichlet boundary condition on only one component of a vertor variable and ignore the other components. Is there any built-in boundary conditions that can be used in moose?
It seems that DirichletBC can impose dirichlet doundary condition on a scalar variable, and VectorDirichletBC can deal with vector variables but cannot pick a specific component.
Thanks for your help！

I think, the AD version of VectorNodalBC as ADVectorDirichletBC and ADVectorFunctionDirichletBC has params: set_x_comp, set_y_comp, set_z_comp. To ignore one or two components of the vector, just set those parameter to false.
Thanks for your reply. I found these parameters in ADVectorMatchedValueBC.
Yes，ADVectorFunctionDirichletBC works well for my issue, thank you

node.title: Rendering top and bottom boundary set on a stacked mesh
node.bodyText:
Issue Description
Hello. I've been trying to get an axial stack of hexagonal blocks with the top boundary set(max z) and the bottom boundary set(min z) separately defined. Looking up the StackGenerator documentation, I thought I could achieve that with front_boundary and back_boundary option.
[Mesh]
    [hex]
        type = PolygonConcentricCircleMeshGenerator
        num_sides = 6
        num_sectors_per_side = '2 2 2 2 2 2'
        ring_radii = '0.01 0.015'
        ring_intervals = '1 1'
        ring_block_ids = '11 12'
        polygon_size = 0.02
        background_block_ids = 70
        quad_center_elements = True
    []
    [extrude]
        type = MeshExtruderGenerator
        input = hex
        extrusion_vector = '0 0 .70'
    []
    [stack_them]
        type = StackGenerator
        inputs = 'extrude extrude extrude'
        dim = 3
        front_boundary=front
        back_boundary=back
        show_info = True
    []
[]

But this did not create any boundary set named front or back in the resulting mesh. I got the same results when I tried with top_boundary and bottom_boundary.
The next approach I took was using SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator:
[Mesh]
    [hex]
        type = PolygonConcentricCircleMeshGenerator
        num_sides = 6
        num_sectors_per_side = '2 2 2 2 2 2'
        ring_radii = '0.01 0.015'
        ring_intervals = '1 1'
        ring_block_ids = '11 12'
        polygon_size = 0.02
        background_block_ids = 70
        quad_center_elements = True
    []
    [extrude]
        type = MeshExtruderGenerator
        input = hex
        extrusion_vector = '0 0 .70'
    []
    [bot_side]
        type = SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator
        input = extrude
        new_boundary = bottom
        replace = True
        normal = '0 0 -1'
        external_only = True
        block = '70'
        output=True
    []
    [top_side]
        type = SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator
        input = extrude
        new_boundary = top
        replace = True
        normal = '0 0 1'
        external_only = True
        block = '70'
        output=True
    []
    [stack_them]
        type = StackGenerator
        inputs = 'bot_side extrude top_side'
        dim = 3
        show_info = True
    []
[]

This did create boundaries at the top and bottom, but they were not defined separately; both upper and lower boundaries were amalgamated as bottom and had the same id. Looking up intermediate meshes from top_side and bot_side, top_side had top boundary set and bot_side had bottom boundary set and they did share the same id.
I thought their ids were not shifted properly since bot_side and top_side parallel to each other(in terms of meshing hierarchy) so I tried my last approach before posting this discussion:

[Mesh]
    [hex]
        type = PolygonConcentricCircleMeshGenerator
        num_sides = 6
        num_sectors_per_side = '2 2 2 2 2 2'
        ring_radii = '0.01 0.015'
        ring_intervals = '1 1'
        ring_block_ids = '11 12'
        polygon_size = 0.02
        background_block_ids = 70
        quad_center_elements = True
    []
    [extrude]
        type = MeshExtruderGenerator
        input = hex
        extrusion_vector = '0 0 .70'
    []
    [bot_side]
        type = SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator
        input = extrude
        new_boundary = bottom
        replace = True
        normal = '0 0 -1'
        external_only = True
        block = '70'
        output=True
    []
    [top_side]
        type = SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator
        input = bot_side
        new_boundary = top
        replace = True
        normal = '0 0 1'
        external_only = True
        block = '70'
        output=True
    []
    [top_side2]
        type = SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator
        input = top_side
        new_boundary = removal
        replace = True
        normal = '0 0 -1'
        external_only = True
        block = '70'
        output=True
    []
    [stack_them]
        type = StackGenerator
        inputs = 'bot_side extrude top_side2'
        dim = 3
        show_info = True
    []
[]

Is there anything I am missing or any other approach I can take here?

Hello
Everyone here uses this one
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/AdvancedExtruderGenerator.html
to perform multi-stage extrusions.
It will have much better machinery to add sidesets, introduce axial mesh biases etc
StackGenerator is not used much, I didn't even know about it.
Guillaume

@GiudGiud
Thanks for the suggestion. Will this also work with axially heterogeneous cases? I guess I have to use id swap to do that?

It will as long as the axial layers are all radially the same (can be stitched together)
I dont think you need id swaps?

Yes.
I dont think we rely under the hood on the StitchedMG but it s the same requirement

in general libmesh only handles non-conformal meshes if they are the output of adaptive refinement
OR if you have custom treatment (eg not regular kernels)

@GiudGiud
Thanks for all the answers! It seems AdvancedExtruderGenerator works quite well w/ ParsedGenerateSideset

node.title: Assigning and updating material property to an element
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
Hope you are doing well.
I wanted to see if we can assign a property to a block, and it gets updated in each element. To make it clear, consider a two region system which in the right-hand side we have a solution which its property (such as density, viscosity, etc.) is dependent on the gas concentration which is injected. I saw a similar question #20334 but I wanted to check if I need to write the material property myself or it has been added.
Best regards,
Sina

Hello
This is actually the default for material properties, they are computed for every quadrature point even.
Constant or constant per-block are optimizations to compute the material properties less-often.
If your material property definition is simple enough to write in an anaytical expression, you could consider using a ParsedMaterial to try it out, with any local variable dependencies. And then you can use the output parameter of the Material to look at its variation in the exodus file
Guillaume

Dear @GiudGiud
Thanks for your reply. I checked the ParsedMaterial as you said and that's exactly what I needed. My question is that how I can pass this calculated material as a function? I get the property that I need for example density, now I need to pass it to my fluid property module which accepts functions. Or better to ask how I can use this property and not only see it's change in the output. Sorry if it is a basic question.
Thanks.
Sina

Which FluidProperty object are you trying to use?
Functions are not supposed to depend on variables, only on time and space.
However, if the fluid property object queries the functions with x = temperature for example, this can work.
It's what this does:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/userobjects/TemperaturePressureFunctionFluidProperties.html

I am using TemperaturePressureFunctionFluidProperties as you mentioned. It accepts functions as input, so I was wondering if I can pass the property calculated by ParsedMaterial which is dependent on the variable to my fluid property. If this cannot be done, do you have any other suggestion?

Oh then you should use ParsedFunctions.
Please be careful when writing down the expressions
x = temperature
y = Pressure
anything else wont be correct

Thank you for your quick reply dear @GiudGiud. Just to double check then, there is no way to pass a variable-dependent material to the fluid properties to update density, vicosity, and etc? and I need to write my own material and fluid property? Thank you in advance for your time.

Nope, no way to pass a material property to a fluid property right now.
It would not be hard to do if you want to add it.
You do not need to write your own material & fluid property if you are willing to use
TemperaturePressureFunctionFluidProperties + ParsedFunctions
or any of the other pre-made FluidProperties

Unfortunatly, TemperaturePressureFunctionFluidProperties + ParsedFunctions or other FluidProperties do not work for me or I could not find a sutable one. I need to only write a FluidProperty which accepts the ParsedMaterial. I appreciate if you have any advice or similar work suggestion to look at. Thanks.
Can you write down your fluid properties here as analytical expressions? I can try to write the ParsedFunctions for you

Oh thank you. I do not have special analytical expression in my mind just wanted to check to see if it works and apply it later.
Here is what I did. I know that you mentioned TemperaturePressureFunctionFluidProperties only works for temperature and pressure correctly but I passed the saturation and it almost gives what I want. However, instead of changing the property at the element that saturation reaches, it changes the whole block. The ParsedMaterial that you mentioned do it right.
Here is my input file.
https://github.com/sinaomrani96/Material-property/blob/main/input.i
Thanks.

ok so the constant are fine as they are, you do not need to specify the symbol_names/vars.
If you have pressure OR temperature dependence, as I mentioned you can use x and y in the function expression.
However, for the pore pressure there's no solution with ParsedFunctions
Creating a new fluid properties that retrieves other material properties will be the way to go if your other objects expert a FluidProperties input

Dear @GiudGiud,
Hope you are doing well.
I followed your instruction, and when I compile I get the following error:
error: cannot convert 'const MaterialProperty' to 'libMesh::Real' {aka 'double'} in return
436 |   return _viscosity1;
|          ^~~~~~~~~~~
|          |
|          const MaterialProperty
Would you please give me an insight into fixing this?
Thanks.
Sina

Try return _viscosity1[_qp]
this retrieves the material property at the quadrature point
also an issue here, the material property must be a reference, not a value
so in the header you need
Const MaterialProperty & _viscosity1

Dear @GiudGiud,
Thanks for your quick reply. I tried to retrieves the material property at the quadrature point as you mentioned and _viscosity1[_qp] gave me the following error:
error: '_qp' was not declared in this scope; did you mean '_cp'?
436 |   return _viscosity1[_qp];
|                      ^~~
|                      _cp
I changed it to _viscosity1[_cp], and it compiles but when I run my simulation it does not converge at the very beginning.
I run it in debug mode and I get:
Assertion `i < _size' failed
Access out of bounds in MooseArray (i: 4194 size: 216)
at /home/sinaomrani/projects/moose/framework/build/header_symlinks/MooseArray.h, line 276
I appreciate it if you have any suggestion. Sorry if this is a basic question.

in which routine is this?
Can you share the code?
_cp is not an index as far as I know.

I am using PorousFlow, and created these two based on SimlpeFluidProperties, and substituting viscosity.
https://github.com/sinaomrani96/Material-property

yeah this isnt going to work..
The fluid property doesn't know the indexing into material properties. So it can't retrieve them.
What's the expression for viscosity?
Oh. I do not have any specific expression in mind, just wanted to connect the viscosity to a variable which I need later. So, what is your suggestion so I can proceed with this?
is this variable pressure, temperature or pore pressure?
Actually it is gas saturation and pressure.

Are these used in porous flow routinely?
I m thinking there will be a better base class to add your new property there (mu(p, sat))
@cpgr for guidance please
as you can see in SimpleFP and in most properties in the fluid properties module, properties are either:
property(p,T) or property(specific energy, specific volume)
Yes I guess. I will wait to see if @cpgr has a suggestion. You are correct. I am trying to find a better base class. Thanks for your help.

It might be because it is too early in the morning, but I'm not sure exactly what you are trying to do? Is viscosity a nonlinear variable in your model? I'm struggling to see how it depends on saturation?
In any case, the FluidProperties module doesn't really know about variables or the mesh, so probably isn't the right place for this.
If you are using porous flow, could you just make your own fluid properties material (inherit from PorousFlowSingleComponentFluid) and swap out the viscosity calculation with your viscosity variable?
So this bit
(*_viscosity)[_qp] = _fp.mu_from_p_T(_porepressure[_qp][_phase_num] * _pressure_to_Pascals,
                                         _temperature[_qp] + _t_c2k) /
                         _pressure_to_Pascals / _time_to_seconds;

might become simply
(*_viscosity)[_qp] = _viscosity1[_qp]

while the rest of the properties come from a fluid properties user object like normal?

Dear @cpgr, good morning then :)))
My viscosity is actually dependent on the gas saturation which is a variable and pressure which is also a variable. So, I used a ParsedMaterial to get this and would like to pass it to viscosity.
I tested your suggestion and I face this error that I cannot fix.
error: 'getMaterialProperty' was not declared in this scope; did you mean 'ADMaterialProperty'?
   34 |     _viscosity1(getMaterialProperty<Real>("viscosity1"))
      |                 ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
      |                 ADMaterialProperty

Should I add or modify something else?
getMaterialProperty<Real>

Dear @GiudGiud,
getMaterialProperty<Real> also did not work but  _viscosity1(this->template getMaterialProperty<Real>("viscosity1")) worked and compiled. However, the simulation does not converge from the beginning even with constant viscosity. I think I should learn more about MOOSE, PorousFlow, and also C++ to solve this but any suggestion from you or Chris is most welcomed. Thanks for the help.

You should be able to modify one of the tests in porous flow that use SimpleFluidProperties (as this uses a constant viscosity). If you then swap in your material with the same constant viscosity you should get the same results. If not, I guess something is incorrect in your implementation.
I'd be happy to take a look if you link to your code (although it is now night-time here so I won't look until tomorrow)

Sure. That would be great. I worked on it and this is the best that I could get. It compiles, and if I pass a constant value to viscosity1 it works. However, if I call the ParsedMaterial even with a constant value the simulation do not converge at the very beginning. Here is link to the material I wrote based on PorousFlowSingleComponentFluid, and my input file.
https://github.com/sinaomrani96/Material-property
Thanks.

You have some inconsistencies there
the computeQpProperty relies half on viscosity1, half on the fp.mu_from_p_T
These lines for example
https://github.com/sinaomrani96/Material-property/blob/09dcc35daf4f4e9bcc4203f6cd185c34642ad3b0/MyFluid.C#L78
https://github.com/sinaomrani96/Material-property/blob/09dcc35daf4f4e9bcc4203f6cd185c34642ad3b0/MyFluid.C#L97
Dear @GiudGiud, Thanks. I fixed those but still facing the same issue.

Still some problems:

AD version, you use raw_value, so you lose the derivative
non AD version, the derivatives are wrong. dmu/dP is not mu / dt, you need to compute a derivative

Yeah, as @GiudGiud said, your derivatives aren't correct.
Looking at your example input file, you want a model with 2 phases, a liquid phase (just using water properties like normal), and a gas phase where the viscosity is mu(p, S)? Is that right?

Yes I am working on the derivatives to figure it out.
It may sound a weird right now because I want to brake my problem into simpler one and solve it step by step. Considering this, It is a two phase model which has a liquid phase which has water properties on the left block and a liquid which it viscosity is mu(p, S) on the right block. So, when gas is injected from the left, the right fluid has a constant viscosity until gas reaches to the right block. I thought that maybe assigning same phase to both these liquid is the problem but as I checked this is not the reason. Also model works when a constant viscosity is assigned to the right liquid.
Sorry to make it more clear, I want the viscosity of the liquid on the right block to be dependent on the gas saturation.

Dear @GiudGiud and @cpgr,
I just wanted to give an update that the problem is now solved and the issue was the BCs. Since I was using PorousFlowPiecewiseLinearSink, and it uses the mobility I was facing the problem. When I use use_mobility = false the model works. I need more work on the BCs but in general it is fine. Thanks for your help.
